title: Ticket #2507: Partitionable slots devolving into regular slots
description:
Submitting jobs against some partitionable slots results in the slots transforming into regular slots, instead of peeling new dynamic slots off and leaving the original part. slots intact.

REPRO:

use this configuration: 

NEGOTIATOR_DEBUG = D_FULLDEBUG
SCHEDD_INTERVAL	= 15

NUM_CPUS = 20
SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=4
SLOT_TYPE_1_PARTITIONABLE = TRUE
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 5

Start up the pool, and you should see 5 partitionable slots (code "P", below): 

$ condor_status -for "%s" Machine -for " | %s" 'ifThenElse(PartitionableSlot =?= TRUE, "P", ifThenElse(DynamicSlot =?= TRUE, "D", "S"))' -for " | %s" State -for " | %s" Activity -for " | %s\n" Cpus
rorschach.localdomain | P | Unclaimed | Idle | 4
rorschach.localdomain | P | Unclaimed | Idle | 4
rorschach.localdomain | P | Unclaimed | Idle | 4
rorschach.localdomain | P | Unclaimed | Idle | 4
rorschach.localdomain | P | Unclaimed | Idle | 4

(note that the command above can display "P" -> "partitionable", "D" --> "dynamic" and "S" --> regular slot)

Now submit 10 jobs, which ought to be able to run by peeling off 10 dynamic slots: 

universe = vanilla
cmd = /bin/sleep
args = 1800
should_transfer_files = if_needed
when_to_transfer_output = on_exit
+AccountingGroup="a.user"
queue 10

After submitting the job above, and waiting a couple cycles, we would hope to see 5 partitionable slots ("P") and 10 dynamic slots ("D"), but what we see instead are only 5 regular slots ("S") (and only 5 jobs running): 

$ condor_submit t.jsub
Submitting job(s)..........
10 job(s) submitted to cluster 2.

# only five jobs ran
$ condor_q | tail -1
10 jobs; 5 idle, 5 running, 0 held

# only regular slots!
$ condor_status -for "%s" Machine -for " | %s" 'ifThenElse(PartitionableSlot =?= TRUE, "P", ifThenElse(DynamicSlot =?= TRUE, "D", "S"))' -for " | %s" State -for " | %s" Activity -for " | %s\n" Cpus
rorschach.localdomain | S | Claimed | Busy | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Claimed | Busy | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Claimed | Busy | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Claimed | Busy | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Claimed | Busy | 1

Removing the jobs does not return our original slots back: 

$ condor_rm -all
All jobs marked for removal.

$ condor_q | tail -1
0 jobs; 0 idle, 0 running, 0 held

$ condor_status -for "%s" Machine -for " | %s" 'ifThenElse(PartitionableSlot =?= TRUE, "P", ifThenElse(DynamicSlot =?= TRUE, "D", "S"))' -for " | %s" State -for " | %s" Activity -for " | %s\n" Cpus
rorschach.localdomain | S | Unclaimed | Idle | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Unclaimed | Idle | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Unclaimed | Idle | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Unclaimed | Idle | 1
rorschach.localdomain | S | Unclaimed | Idle | 1

2011-Sep-27 19:10:39 by matt:
#1943 and sha 7d968fe0 changed Resource's constructor signature, but missed the dynamic slot creation in command.cpp 

diff --git a/src/condor_startd.V6/command.cpp b/src/condor_startd.V6/command.cpp
index 3bde265..1f800c5 100644
--- a/src/condor_startd.V6/command.cpp
+++ b/src/condor_startd.V6/command.cpp
@@ -1221,7 +1221,7 @@ request_claim( Resource* rip, Claim *claim, char* id, Stream* stream )
                        ABORT;
                }

-               new_rip = new Resource( cpu_attrs, rip->r_id, rip );
+               new_rip = new Resource( cpu_attrs, rip->r_id, true, rip );
                if( ! new_rip ) {
                        rip->dprintf( D_ALWAYS,
                                                  "Failed to build new resource for request, aborting\n" );

We need a regression test for dynamic slots.
